channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: Pregnant woman killed in suspected DUI crash in Anaheim
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: A woman who was 35 weeks pregnant was killed Tuesday night in a suspected DUI crash in Anaheim, authorities said.
item.content:encoded: A woman who was 35 weeks pregnant was killed Tuesday night in a suspected DUI crash in Anaheim, authorities said.

item.title: Column: In California Sen. Kamala Harris, Biden chooses a VP hailing from our most diverse state
item.dc:creator: George Skelton
item.description: California is also a state of immigrants. And fittingly, Sen. Kamala Harris is the daughter of immigrant parents — a father from Jamaica, a mother from India.
item.content:encoded: California is also a state of immigrants. And fittingly, Sen. Kamala Harris is the daughter of immigrant parents — a father from Jamaica, a mother from India.

media:content.media:description: Vice President Joe Biden, right, shakes hands with Sen. Kamala Harris, D-Calif., as her husband Douglas Emhoff, looks on during a a mock swearing in ceremony in the Old Senate Chamber on Capitol Hill in Washington, Tuesday, Jan. 3, 2017, as the 115th Congress begins. (AP Photo/Kevin Wolf)

item.title: L.A. school board approves deal on remote learning; critics say it falls short on teaching
item.dc:creator: Howard Blume
item.description: L.A. Board of Education approves agreement with union for structured online teaching. Critics say it needlessly shortens the traditional school day.
item.content:encoded: L.A. Board of Education approves agreement with union for structured online teaching. Critics say it needlessly shortens the traditional school day.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 07: Los Angeles Unified School District Superintendent Austin Beutner demonstrates the use of sanitizing tools while taking a tour of Burbank Middle School with Principal Christine Moore on Friday, Aug. 7, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. As the academic school year looms, preparations have been under way to make campuses safe inside and out, even though the school year will start with distance-learning only because of the surging coronavirus pandemic. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: De León expected to take over seat of suspended L.A. Councilman Huizar in October
item.dc:creator: Emily Alpert Reyes
item.description: The council president has set out plans for a "caretaker" to manage Huizar's district until former state Senate Leader Kevin de León is appointed in October.
item.content:encoded: The council president has set out plans for a "caretaker" to manage Huizar's district until former state Senate Leader Kevin de León is appointed in October.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIFORNIAÑFEB. 5, 2020ÑFormer State Sen. Kevin de Leon takes part in a pre-election forum for the LA City Council 14th District in Little Tokyo on Feb. 5, 2020. The candidates for Los Angeles City Council in the 14th District take part in a candidate forum in Little Tokyo on Feb. 5, 2020. (Carolyn Cole/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Heat watch issued for much of Southern California this weekend
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: The National Weather Service has issued an excessive heat watch for much of Southern California this weekend, forecasting that temperatures will near record highs throughout the region.
item.content:encoded: The National Weather Service has issued an excessive heat watch for much of Southern California this weekend, forecasting that temperatures will near record highs throughout the region.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 11: Pedestrians are required to wear a mask and practice social distancing when visiting Main Street in downtown Ventura which has been closed to vehicle traffic to allow restaurants and businesses to accommodate for outdoor dining and shopping in the era of the Covid-19 Coronavirus pandemic on August 11, 2020. Los Angeles on Tuesday, Aug. 11, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Mayor Garcetti's top homelessness advisor to resign
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Oreskes
item.description: Mayor Eric Garcetti's top advisor on homelessness, Deputy Mayor Christina Miller, has told colleagues that she plans to resign at the end of the month.
item.content:encoded: Mayor Eric Garcetti's top advisor on homelessness, Deputy Mayor Christina Miller, has told colleagues that she plans to resign at the end of the month.

media:content.media:description: Deputy Mayor of Los Angeles, Christina Miller. She was Mayor Garcetti's top adviser on homelessness.

item.title: Family of dead woman allegedly groped by LAPD officer files lawsuit
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: While on duty, an LAPD officer allegedly fondled the breasts of a woman he had found dead. Her family is suing the officer and the city of L.A.
item.content:encoded: While on duty, an LAPD officer allegedly fondled the breasts of a woman he had found dead. Her family is suing the officer and the city of L.A.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 11: Janet Baggett, mother of the late Elizabeth Baggett, wipes her eyes as Attorney Gloria Allred speaks at a press conference on Tuesday, Aug. 11, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Allred's film, Allred, Maroko & Goldberg, filed the lawsuit on behalf of the estate of Elizabeth Baggett, whose dead body was allegedly fondled by an on-duty Los Angeles Police Department officer. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Los Angeles County tops 5,000 coronavirus deaths
item.dc:creator: Joseph Serna, Phil Willon, Laura J. Nelson
item.description: The county's infection rate is substantially lower than Central Valley counties where case rates are surging
item.content:encoded: The county's infection rate is substantially lower than Central Valley counties where case rates are surging

media:content.media:description: COLTON, CA - APRIL 09: Alejandra Ortiz, left, sits in her car as a nurse administers a coronavirus COVID-19 test at Arrowhead Regional Medical Center durning public testing drive-through in Colton, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: With Kamala Harris as Biden's VP pick, Newsom has a chance to appoint history-making senator
item.dc:creator: Phil Willon
item.description: The appointment promises to be one of the most consequential of his political career, both in California and in regard to any ambitions he may have for White House.
item.content:encoded: The appointment promises to be one of the most consequential of his political career, both in California and in regard to any ambitions he may have for White House.

media:content.media:description: Sen. Kamala Harris, left, endorses California Lt. Gov. Gavin Newsom for the 2018 California Governor's race at the Ronald Tutor Campus Center at the University of Southern California in Los Angeles, Friday, Feb. 16, 2018. (AP Photo/Damian Dovarganes)

item.title: How has the COVID-19 pandemic affected your commute?
item.dc:creator: Laura J. Nelson
item.description: The pandemic has forced thousands of workplaces to quickly adjust to remote work. Will your employer keep some of those changes in place permanently?
item.content:encoded: The pandemic has forced thousands of workplaces to quickly adjust to remote work. Will your employer keep some of those changes in place permanently?

media:content.media:description: ONTARIO, CA - MAY 08: The morning commute on the southbound 15 Freeway in Ontario was slightly busier May 8 than in prior weeks. Freeway I-15 on Friday, May 8, 2020 in Ontario, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Pew poll finds most Latinos haven't heard of 'Latinx.' Only 3% use the term
item.dc:creator: Daniel Hernandez
item.description: Some three out of four Latinos in the U.S. haven't heard of the term 'Latinx,' but its use may grow.
item.content:encoded: Some three out of four Latinos in the U.S. haven't heard of the term 'Latinx,' but its use may grow.

media:content.media:description: A woman waves a U.S. flag as marchers make their way down Broadway in downtown Los Angeles during a 2011 May Day event calling for immigration reform.

item.title: Cow chase leads to helicopter rescue in Solano County
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: Two people encountered a bad-tempered bovine at Lynch Canyon Open Space Park and were injured while fleeing. A helicopter rescue followed the cow chase.
item.content:encoded: Two people encountered a bad-tempered bovine at Lynch Canyon Open Space Park and were injured while fleeing. A helicopter rescue followed the cow chase.

media:content.media:description: An elderly couple was injured and had to be airlifted out of a Solano County park Sunday after falling while being chased by a cow, authorities said.
media:content.media:credit: California Highway Patrol, Golden Gate Division Air Operations

item.title: Child is first person in Orange County to contract West Nile virus this year
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: Ten other human West Nile virus cases have been confirmed statewide in 2020, eight in Stanislaus County, and the others in L.A. and Madera counties.
item.content:encoded: Ten other human West Nile virus cases have been confirmed statewide in 2020, eight in Stanislaus County, and the others in L.A. and Madera counties.

media:content.media:description: How did this mosquito pick this particular victim? The victim's genes likely played a big role, a new study suggests.

item.title: Five injured in shooting at large Harbor Gateway warehouse party
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: At about 12:30 a.m. Tuesday, an unknown assailant opened fire at a warehouse party in L.A.'s Harbor Gateway area, authorities said.
item.content:encoded: At about 12:30 a.m. Tuesday, an unknown assailant opened fire at a warehouse party in L.A.'s Harbor Gateway area, authorities said.

media:content.media:description: TORRANCE, CA - AUGUST 11: LAPD officers Chris Lindberg, left, and Blake Putnins investigating a shooting at a large party in a warehouse in the Harbor Gateway area that sent five people to a hospital early Tuesday morning. The incident occurred around 12:30 a.m. when an unknown assailant opened fire at the gathering in the 22900 block of Lockness Avenue in Tuesday, Aug. 11, 2020 in Torrance, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Defund the LAPD? At this pace, it would take 20 years to hit Black Lives Matter's goal
item.dc:creator: David Zahniser, Adam Elmahrek, Priya Krishnakumar
item.description: Even with budget cuts, police spending in Los Angeles will reach about $3 billion a year. How did the LAPD come to consume to much of the city's 'unrestricted' money?
item.content:encoded: Even with budget cuts, police spending in Los Angeles will reach about $3 billion a year. How did the LAPD come to consume to much of the city's 'unrestricted' money?

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 02: LA Mayor Eric Garcetti walks out to address protesters and clergy members from the Los Angeles area that are participating in a march and peaceful protest in downtown Los Angeles outside of LA City Hall and LAPD Headquarters on Tuesday, June 2, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Protests erupted across the country, with people outraged over the death of George Floyd, a black man killed after a white Minneapolis police officer pinned him to the ground with his knee. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Google adds California's earthquake early warning system into Android phones
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: Google is adding California's earthquake early warning system as part of its Android operating system for mobile phones.
item.content:encoded: Google is adding California's earthquake early warning system as part of its Android operating system for mobile phones.

media:content.media:description: Javaid Waseem, owner of Minit Gas Station and store on Ridgecrest Blvd., whose store was hit by Thursday quake once again hit by earthquake on Friday in Ridgecrest.

item.title: Amid COVID-19 pandemic, people with diabetes struggle to get insulin
item.dc:creator: Tiffany Wong
item.description: One in four people with diabetes have rationed supplies to cut the cost of their diabetes care since the start of the pandemic, a survey found.
item.content:encoded: One in four people with diabetes have rationed supplies to cut the cost of their diabetes care since the start of the pandemic, a survey found.

media:content.media:description: VAN NUYS, CA -AUGUST 05, 2020: Diabetes patient Adam Winney is photographed inside his apartment in Van Nuys next to 1000 unit samples of fast acting insulin that he received from his doctor. Winney said that each sample lasts him about 3 weeks. A bill is stuck in the Senate health committee right now that would cap insulin costs to $50 a month. Adam, who is currently unemployed because of the coronavirus outbreak, has been living off of the samples from his doctor since he can't afford to pay $1000 a month for insulin. (Mel Melcon / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: San Quentin's coronavirus outbreak shows why 'herd immunity' could mean disaster
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Kim Christensen
item.description: Public health experts say the rampant spread of the coronavirus at the prison shows the dangers of trying to achieve 'herd immunity' with the coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: Public health experts say the rampant spread of the coronavirus at the prison shows the dangers of trying to achieve 'herd immunity' with the coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: A condemned prisoner holds the mesh fence in the exercise yard during a media tour at San Quentin prison.

item.title: Across from City Hall, a protest encampment is a 'reminder' of need for police reform
item.dc:creator: James Queally
item.description: For more than six weeks, a group of protesters have camped out across from L.A. City Hall, forming a protest community that has grown into a constant symbol of calls for police reform.
item.content:encoded: For more than six weeks, a group of protesters have camped out across from L.A. City Hall, forming a protest community that has grown into a constant symbol of calls for police reform.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 24: Jason Morales, 34, from Pacoima, is living with a group of people with the shared goal of promoting Black unity in an encampment in Grand Park on Friday, July 24, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: The LAPD branded these two brothers MS-13 gang members. Prosecutors say they were deliberately framed
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth, Dorany Pineda
item.description: Early on a Thursday morning in February, two men in suits rapped on the door of the South Los Angeles apartment that Gadseel Quiñonez shares with his little brother.
item.content:encoded: Early on a Thursday morning in February, two men in suits rapped on the door of the South Los Angeles apartment that Gadseel Quiñonez shares with his little brother.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 05: Gadseel Quinonez, 29, right, and his brother Jose Quinonez, 18, left, stand for a portrait at the recycling center where they work on Wednesday, Aug. 5, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. The brothers are among dozens of people who county prosecutors say were falsely labeled as gang members or associates by three LAPD officers from the department's Metropolitan Division. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: LAPD officer hospitalized after being struck by possibly impaired driver in South L.A.
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: An LAPD officer was hospitalized Monday night with non-life-threatening injuries after being struck by a possibly impaired motorist in South L.A., authorities said.
item.content:encoded: An LAPD officer was hospitalized Monday night with non-life-threatening injuries after being struck by a possibly impaired motorist in South L.A., authorities said.

item.title: L.A. County may pay $1.35 million to settle case over use of public funds to back Measure H
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: A probe by the state's political watchdog and a civil lawsuit have resulted in a settlement that would require L.A. County to pay $1.35 million to resolve claims that it failed to report public funds to support a 2017 homeless services tax ballot measure.
item.content:encoded: A probe by the state's political watchdog and a civil lawsuit have resulted in a settlement that would require L.A. County to pay $1.35 million to resolve claims that it failed to report public funds to support a 2017 homeless services tax ballot measure.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. -- FRIDAY, MARCH 17, 2017: LA County supervisor Mark Ridley-Thomas, center, andLos Angeles mayor Eric Garcetti, right, and with supporters of ballot Measure H as the final vote tallies are announced passing by 69.24% during a United Way event in Los Angeles, Calif., on March 17, 2017. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Police union to Garcetti: Don't drag cops into your 'party house' plan
item.dc:creator: Dakota Smith
item.description: The union representing Los Angeles police officers is criticizing Mayor Eric Garcetti's plan to shut off water and power at "party houses," saying officers should be focused on the rising number of shootings instead.
item.content:encoded: The union representing Los Angeles police officers is criticizing Mayor Eric Garcetti's plan to shut off water and power at "party houses," saying officers should be focused on the rising number of shootings instead.

media:content.media:description: Aerial view of a large house party on Mulholland Drive in Beverly Crest, where three people were shot.

item.title: Black teens who were victims of a knife attack had guns drawn on them by deputies, lawyer says
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: In a video of the incident, a woman can be heard telling deputies she called 911 to report that the teens were being chased by a man with a knife.
item.content:encoded: In a video of the incident, a woman can be heard telling deputies she called 911 to report that the teens were being chased by a man with a knife.

media:content.media:description: A vote on a proposal to set up an oversight commission of the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department was delayed by the Board of Supervisors.

item.title: Vicky Lindsey, Compton's passionate advocate for mothers of homicide victims, dies
item.dc:creator: Nicole Santa Cruz
item.description: Vicky Lindsey, 62, helped women whose children have been killed cope.
item.content:encoded: Vicky Lindsey, 62, helped women whose children have been killed cope.

media:content.media:description: Activists Vicky Lindsey, center, Pam Carolina, left, and Teresa Haro pose with a billboard showing murder victims in urging a stop to violence in Compton. Lindsey has helped many victims' families since her son was killed 20 years ago

item.title: Newsom tries to quell furor over data errors after administration shakeup
item.dc:creator: Phil Willon, Taryn Luna, Melody Gutierrez
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom faced reporters for the first time since he touted the inaccurate coronavirus data as a positive sign of fewer COVID-19 infections a day before the glitches became public. The governor said he was kept in the dark about the problem, even as state health officials were warning counties about data issues days earlier.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom faced reporters for the first time since he touted the inaccurate coronavirus data as a positive sign of fewer COVID-19 infections a day before the glitches became public. The governor said he was kept in the dark about the problem, even as state health officials were warning counties about data issues days earlier.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this May 14, 2020, file photo, California Gov. Gavin Newsom discusses his revised 2020-2021 state budget during a news conference in Sacramento, Calif. The California Senate's plan to cover a projected budget deficit rejects Gov. Gavin Newsom's proposed cuts to public education and health care programs. Newsom's plan would cut funding for public schools by about $8 billion. The Senate's plan would restore $2.7 billion of those cuts, the rest being deferred to future years. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, Pool, File)

item.title: Coronavirus surging among children, teenagers in California
item.dc:creator: Laura J. Nelson
item.description: Coronavirus cases among children and teenagers are surging in California, up 150% last month, a rate that outpaces COVID-19 cases overall and establishes minors as a small but growing share of the state's COVID-19 cases.
item.content:encoded: Coronavirus cases among children and teenagers are surging in California, up 150% last month, a rate that outpaces COVID-19 cases overall and establishes minors as a small but growing share of the state's COVID-19 cases.

media:content.media:description: Sharon Chavez, 26, use the oral swab on her 7-year-old daughter Melany Garcia to test for Coronavirus the parking lot of a Food4Less Grocery in the Westlake area.

item.title: Swarm of Salton Sea earthquakes sparks worry about the San Andreas fault
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: Swarm of Salton Sea earthquakes sparks worry about the San Andreas fault
item.content:encoded: Swarm of Salton Sea earthquakes sparks worry about the San Andreas fault

media:content.media:description: Earthquakes as large as magnitude 4.6 under the Salton Sea are raising concern that a larger earthquake could be unleashed on the San Andreas fault, the southernmost section of which has not ruptured since about 1680.

item.title: Trump's unemployment benefit plan won't work in California, Newsom says
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy, John Myers
item.description: Newsom and others called on federal officials to overcome a stalemate involving Congress and the president to provide additional funding for states.
item.content:encoded: Newsom and others called on federal officials to overcome a stalemate involving Congress and the president to provide additional funding for states.

media:content.media:description: Gov. Gavin Newsom discusses his revised 2019-2020 state budget during a news conference Thursday, May 9, 2019, in Sacramento, Calif. Newsom, a Democrat, has proposed a $213.5 billion a spending plan. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli)

item.title: After record-high deaths, COVID-19 hospitalizations decline in Inland Empire
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: Last week, both San Bernardino and Riverside counties reported record single-day tallies of coronavirus-related deaths.
item.content:encoded: Last week, both San Bernardino and Riverside counties reported record single-day tallies of coronavirus-related deaths.

media:content.media:description: SAN BERNARDINO, CA -JULY28: Responding to recent spikes in positive COVID-19 cases and hospitalizations, San Bernardino County is bringing back Alternate Care Sites (ACS) to handle possible hospital overload while ensuring those who need medical care are able to receive it. An initial ACS has been set up in Parking Lot 14 at Arrowhead Regional Medical Center (ARMC) in Colton and is being referred to as the ACS Village. It is comprised of a nursing unit, patient care areas with 32 beds, an Isolation Pod, and a command center for staff breaks. Arrowhead Regional Medical Center on Tuesday, July 28, 2020 in San Bernardino, CA. (Irfan Khan/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Metro bus fatally strikes man in East L.A., then continues on route
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: California Highway Patrol investigators said the bus driver did not realize the 26-year-old man had been struck by the bus' rear tire in East L.A.
item.content:encoded: California Highway Patrol investigators said the bus driver did not realize the 26-year-old man had been struck by the bus' rear tire in East L.A.

item.title: Swarm of earthquakes shakes Salton Sea area
item.dc:creator: Gary Robbins, Quakebot
item.description: A series of earthquakes Monday shook the California cities of Brawley, Imperial, El Centro, Coachella and La Quinta.
item.content:encoded: A series of earthquakes Monday shook the California cities of Brawley, Imperial, El Centro, Coachella and La Quinta.

media:content.media:description: A magnitude 4.6 earthquake was reported Aug. 10 at 8:56 a.m. Pacific time 19 miles from Brawley, Calif.

item.title: This California school is open, 'learning as we go.' Is it a model or a mistake?
item.dc:creator: Anita Chabria
item.description: Catholic schools in California are seeking waivers to open for in-person learning. In Nevada County, one has gone back to class.
item.content:encoded: Catholic schools in California are seeking waivers to open for in-person learning. In Nevada County, one has gone back to class.

media:content.media:description: GRASS VALLEY, CA - AUGUST 06: China Arkansas, 8, right, of Grass Valley, an incoming third-grader, takes an assessment test while David Pistone, a junior high math and social studies teacher, looks on during a teacher meet and greet at Mount Saint Mary's Academy on Thursday, Aug. 6, 2020 in Grass Valley, CA. Mount Saint Mary's Academy, founded 1859, is a private Catholic TK-8th grade school with 160 students and is the oldest catholic school west of the Mississippi. The Academy's first day of class will be Aug. 17th. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Latino workers bear brunt of second wave of COVID-19 in ritzy Marin County
item.dc:creator: Rachel Scheier
item.description: In Marin County, one of the nation's richest, Latinos account for 16% of the population but 75% of coronavirus cases. Many are essential workers.
item.content:encoded: In Marin County, one of the nation's richest, Latinos account for 16% of the population but 75% of coronavirus cases. Many are essential workers.

media:content.media:description: Jennifer Tores, a lifelong resident of the Canal, arrived at the local COVID-19 testing site 8 a.m. to get in line. The neighborhood is one of the most heavily tested communities in the state, say health officials, who are struggling to control the spread of the virus.

item.title: The all-star economic task force advising Newsom during the pandemic remains a mystery
item.dc:creator: Phil Willon
item.description: California Gov. Gavin Newsom's economic task force has operated almost entirely behind closed doors, and those appointed were not required to submit state government financial disclosure forms listing their assets and business interests, which would show potential conflicts.
item.content:encoded: California Gov. Gavin Newsom's economic task force has operated almost entirely behind closed doors, and those appointed were not required to submit state government financial disclosure forms listing their assets and business interests, which would show potential conflicts.

media:content.media:description: WOODLAND HILLS, CA -JULY 17, 2020: Jason Ruckart, center, a managing partner at Roy's Restaurant in Woodland Hills, hands chopsticks to customers Nicole Lehning, and her husband Kyle, as they dine outdoors. The Lehning's, visiting from Seattle, Washington, said they are on their honeymoon. Fleming's Prime Steakhouse and Roy's Restaurant, located next to each other, converted the valet parking area into outdoor dining. Due to the coronavirus, the restaurants are only allowed to have outdoor dining and takeout as a safety precaution. Valet parking is also not allowed, only self-parking. (Mel Melcon / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'Horrible sequence of mistakes': How bullet train contractors botched a bridge project
item.dc:creator: Ralph Vartabedian
item.description: A bridge that was supposed to take a year is incomplete after four, partly because of corrosion and other problems involving California's high-speed-rail contractors.
item.content:encoded: A bridge that was supposed to take a year is incomplete after four, partly because of corrosion and other problems involving California's high-speed-rail contractors.

media:content.media:description: MADERA, CA - AUGUST 05: A 700 foot bullet train bridge across Road 27, between Road 27 and Club Dr., and the BNSF main line in Madera County had a serious problem with corroded tension strands that broke in December 2019, on Wednesday, Aug. 5, 2020 in Madera, CA. The California High-Speed Rail Authority is making repairs, though the incident points to seriously underlying problems in the project's management. After the strands (steel cables) broke, construction teams shored up the bridge with falsework. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: California should allow its voters to fill U.S. Senate vacancies — not the governor
item.dc:creator: George Skelton
item.description: In California, any vacancy in a statewide elective office can be filled by the governor, subject to legislative confirmation.
item.content:encoded: In California, any vacancy in a statewide elective office can be filled by the governor, subject to legislative confirmation.

media:content.media:description: California Lt. Gov. Gavin Newsom and California Atty. Gen. Kamala Harris, two of the best-known Democrats on the June 3 ballot, are widely seen as unbeatable.

item.title: California's public health director resigns in wake of coronavirus data errors
item.dc:creator: John Myers
item.description: Dr. Sonia Angell, who held the position for less than a year, announced her resignation in an email sent to department staff on Sunday.
item.content:encoded: Dr. Sonia Angell, who held the position for less than a year, announced her resignation in an email sent to department staff on Sunday.

item.title: New COVID-19 testing site set to open near pedestrian crossing in San Ysidro along U.S.-Mexico border
item.dc:creator: LYNDSAY WINKLEY, GUSTAVO SOLIS
item.description: The location is thought to be the closest testing location to the U.S.-Mexico border in any state
item.content:encoded: The location is thought to be the closest testing location to the U.S.-Mexico border in any state

media:content.media:description: SAN YSIDRO, CALIFORNIA - AUGUST 04: Pedestrian traffic at the US/Mexico border at PedEast on Tuesday, Aug. 4, 2020 in San Ysidro, California. (Alejandro Tamayo / The San Diego Union-Tribune)

item.title: San Quentin State Prison guard dies from coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Laura Newberry
item.description: There have been 261 confirmed cases of COVID-19 among staff members at San Quentin, but Polanco is the first correctional officer there to die from the illness, according to state prison officials.
item.content:encoded: There have been 261 confirmed cases of COVID-19 among staff members at San Quentin, but Polanco is the first correctional officer there to die from the illness, according to state prison officials.

media:content.media:description: San Quentin State Prison, opened in 1852 on the shore of San Francisco Bay, is the state's oldest prison and home to California's only death row.

item.title: L.A. County reports more than 1,700 new coronavirus cases, many among younger people
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Los Angeles County public health officials on Sunday reported 1,789 new cases of the coronavirus and 10 deaths.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County public health officials on Sunday reported 1,789 new cases of the coronavirus and 10 deaths.

media:content.media:description: SANTA MONICA, CA - JULY 3, 2020: Bicyclists and a runner wear masks as they enjoy the boardwalk at Santa Monica Beach on Friday as all beaches in L.A. County are closed due to the coronavirus pandemic on July 3, 2020 in Santa Monica, California. (Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Newbury Park church holds indoor services in defiance of judge's order
item.dc:creator: Christopher Goffard
item.description: As many as 150 demonstrators gathered near Newbury Park's Godspeak church, some supporting its defiance of a judge's order, others denouncing the indoor services.
item.content:encoded: As many as 150 demonstrators gathered near Newbury Park's Godspeak church, some supporting its defiance of a judge's order, others denouncing the indoor services.

media:content.media:description: NEWBURY PARK, CA - AUGUST 09: Supporters and protestors gather at Godspeak Calvary Chapel in Newbury Park for Pastor Rob McCoy who defied a judge's order and held indoor services on Sunday, Aug. 9, 2020 in Newbury Park, CA. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Firefighters report progress against 32,000-acre Apple fire in Riverside County
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: The Apple fire had burned 32,412 acres, destroyed four homes and was 40% contained as of Sunday morning.
item.content:encoded: The Apple fire had burned 32,412 acres, destroyed four homes and was 40% contained as of Sunday morning.

media:content.media:description: BANNING, CA - AUGUST 4, 2020: Scorched terrain surrounds a home off Bluff Street as the Apple fire smolders in the background during the coronavirus pandemic on August 4, 2020 in Banning, California. (Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Remains of servicemen who died in California training exercise to be prepared for burial
item.dc:creator: City News Service
item.description: The remains were recovered Friday after the Marines and a sailor went missing near San Clemente Island when their amphibious vehicle sank last month.
item.content:encoded: The remains were recovered Friday after the Marines and a sailor went missing near San Clemente Island when their amphibious vehicle sank last month.

media:content.media:description: The U.S. flag was lowered to half-staff at Park Semper Fi in San Clemente, Calif., on Friday, July 31, 2020. Officials say a military seafaring assault vehicle with 15 Marines and a Navy sailor aboard sank off the coast of Southern California, leaving one of the Marines dead and eight missing. A Marine Corps spokesman says they were traveling in the amphibious assault vehicle from the shores of San Clemente Island to a Navy ship Thursday evening when they reported that the vehicle was taking on water. (Paul Bersebach/The Orange County Register via AP)

item.title: Thousands of online listings are violating L.A.'s new short-term rental law
item.dc:creator: Emily Alpert Reyes, Ben Poston
item.description: More than a year after L.A. clamped down on renting homes for short stays, many rental hosts appear to be ignoring the new law.
item.content:encoded: More than a year after L.A. clamped down on renting homes for short stays, many rental hosts appear to be ignoring the new law.

media:content.media:description: An overflow crowd fills the L.A. City Council chamber Thursday as the Planning Commission considered imposing new regulations on Airbnb and other websites.

item.title: Amid COVID-19, California releases some inmates doing time for murder. Advocates push to free more
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton, Anita Chabria, Kim Christensen
item.description: California has focused on freeing nonviolent offenders to combat the spread of coronavirus in prisons, but some have committed violent crimes.
item.content:encoded: California has focused on freeing nonviolent offenders to combat the spread of coronavirus in prisons, but some have committed violent crimes.

media:content.media:description: Two women hold up a banner before the start of a news conference urging California Gov. Gavin Newsom to release prisoners Thursday, July 9, 2020, in San Quentin, Calif. A group of legislators, advocates, academics, and public health officials gathered at San Quentin State Prison to discuss a COVID-19 outbreak at the facility that has sickened more than 1,400 inmates with six deaths. (AP Photo/Eric Risberg)

item.title: As COVID-19 cases surge, patients are dying at a lower rate. Here's why
item.dc:creator: Soumya Karlamangla
item.description: Even with California's death toll from COVID-19 surpassing 10,000, some hope is emerging: Doctors are getting better at saving patients.
item.content:encoded: Even with California's death toll from COVID-19 surpassing 10,000, some hope is emerging: Doctors are getting better at saving patients.

media:content.media:description: MISSION HILLS, CA - JULY 10: Nurses Janil Wise (CQ), left, and Melinda Gruman, right, look over medical chart for a patient who is pregnant and was exposed to a person with COVID-19, in the OB triage tent at Providence Holy Cross Medical Center on Friday, July 10, 2020 in Mission Hills, CA. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Drought continues to expand as the monsoon in the Southwest has been largely a no-show

item.description: Dry westerly flow over Southern California has kept moisture to the south and east
item.content:encoded: Dry westerly flow over Southern California has kept moisture to the south and east

media:content.media:description: U.S. Drought Monitor data released Thursday show drought expanding in the West.

item.title: Griffith Park's beloved carousel man, Julio Gosdinski, has died at age 49
item.dc:creator: Esmeralda Bermudez
item.description: Julio Gosdinski, dead age 49, had worked at the carousel since he was a teenager. He loved it so much, the owner made him co-owner.
item.content:encoded: Julio Gosdinski, dead age 49, had worked at the carousel since he was a teenager. He loved it so much, the owner made him co-owner.

media:content.media:description: Julio Gosdinski in 2015 with one of his happy carousel customers, Juna Nguyen, now 10 years old.

item.title: Trump supporters march in peaceful demonstration in Beverly Hills
item.dc:creator: City News Service
item.description: Demonstrators carried "Trump 2020" banners, American flags and signs saying "United We Stand."
item.content:encoded: Demonstrators carried "Trump 2020" banners, American flags and signs saying "United We Stand."

item.title: L.A. County coronavirus hospitalizations continue to decline
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Los Angeles County public health officials on Saturday reported 2,645 new cases of COVID-19 and 51 related deaths but said hospitalizations continued to decline.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County public health officials on Saturday reported 2,645 new cases of COVID-19 and 51 related deaths but said hospitalizations continued to decline.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MARCH 04 , 2020 - L.A. County Department of Public Health Director Barbara Ferrer addresses a press conference held at the steps of Kenneth Hahn Hall of Administration to declare a health emergency as the number of coronavirus cases increased to seven, with six new cases in Los Angeles County. None of the new cases are connected to "community spread," officials said. All individuals were exposed to COVID-19 through close contacts. The additional cases were confirmed Tuesday night. Officials said three of the new cases were travelers who had visited northern Italy, two were family members who had close contact with someone outside of the county who was infected, and one had a job that put them in contact with travelers. One person has been hospitalized, and the others are isolated at home. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Irfan Khan/Irfan Khan/Irfan Khan/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Hermosa Beach adds contract officers from private firm to help enforce mask order
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Hermosa Beach is tapping a private consulting firm for personnel to help its police department enforce an ordinance requiring face coverings.
item.content:encoded: Hermosa Beach is tapping a private consulting firm for personnel to help its police department enforce an ordinance requiring face coverings.

media:content.media:description: HERMOSA BEACH, CA --APRIL 02, 2020 - A man wearing a face covering skates along Pier Plaza, in Hermosa Beach, CA, during the coronavirus pandemic and current safer-at-home orders from California Gov. Gavin Newsom, April 02, 2020. (Jay L. Clendenin / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Jay L. Clendenin/Jay L. Clendenin/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Final canister of nuclear waste transferred to storage facility at San Onofre
item.dc:creator: ROB NIKOLEWSKI
item.description: The transfer of dozens of canisters of nuclear waste to a dry storage facility at the San Onofre Nuclear Generating Station wrapped up Friday.
item.content:encoded: The transfer of dozens of canisters of nuclear waste to a dry storage facility at the San Onofre Nuclear Generating Station wrapped up Friday.

media:content.media:description: The final canister at the San Onofre Nuclear Generating Station is lowered Friday Aug. 7 into its enclosure at a dry storage facility that houses 73 individual canisters at the plant.

item.title: Remains of missing Marines, sailor recovered from sunken amphibious vehicle off Southern California coast
item.dc:creator: Andrew Dyer
item.description: Seven Marines and a sailor were lost at sea when their assault amphibious vehicle sank a week ago during training near San Clemente Island.
item.content:encoded: Seven Marines and a sailor were lost at sea when their assault amphibious vehicle sank a week ago during training near San Clemente Island.

media:content.media:description: Undersea Rescue Command deploys the Sibitzky Remotely Operated Vehicle (ROV) from the deck of the Military Sealift Command-chartered merchant vessel HOS Dominator. Undersea Rescue Command is aiding in recovery of the missing seven Marines and one Sailor from the 15th Marine Expeditionary Unit.

item.title: Steve Lopez: In the middle of a pandemic, a miracle came to Father Greg Boyle and Homeboy Industries
item.dc:creator: Steve Lopez
item.description: Working from a tent, and social distancing in earnest, Father Boyle keeps the mission alive — with some help from a $2.5-million award
item.content:encoded: Working from a tent, and social distancing in earnest, Father Boyle keeps the mission alive — with some help from a $2.5-million award

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA -AUGUST06: Fr. Greg Boyle, center, of Homeboy Industries is running the operation from a tent in the parking lot. Homeboy Industries was on brink of budget disaster, then Fr. Boyle just won a $3.5 million humanitarian award, mana from heaven. Homeboy Industries on Thursday, Aug. 6, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Irfan Khan/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: It's time to rethink theme parks. Creative ways to reopen while social distancing
item.dc:creator: Todd Martens
item.description: The coronavirus era offers opportunities to reimagine experiences. It's time to start thinking of the entire park as an attraction.
item.content:encoded: The coronavirus era offers opportunities to reimagine experiences. It's time to start thinking of the entire park as an attraction.

media:content.media:description: BUENA PARK, CA -JULY 31, 2020: Clay Mayfield, above left, dressed up as an outlaw, waves to visitors during Knott's Tase of Calico event at Knott's Ghost Town in Buena Park. Knott's Taste of Calico is a specially ticketed, limited-time outdoor dining and retail experience. (Mel Melcon / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: With L.A. Councilman Jose Huizar arrested and suspended, who's in charge in his district?
item.dc:creator: Emily Alpert Reyes
item.description: With L.A. City Councilman Jose Huizar charged with corruption and suspended from his post, it's now unclear who's running his district office.
item.content:encoded: With L.A. City Councilman Jose Huizar charged with corruption and suspended from his post, it's now unclear who's running his district office.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 06: El Sereno resident Hugo Garcia poses for a portrait on Thursday, Aug. 6, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Many Angelenos remain puzzled about who is actually running the council office of City Councilman Jose Huizar, who has been charged in a corruption probe and suspended from the council. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Coronavirus data failures add to California's struggle to deal with pandemic
item.dc:creator: Taryn Luna, Colleen Shalby, Joe Mozingo
item.description: State officials still scrambling to fix a database tracking coronavirus cases
item.content:encoded: State officials still scrambling to fix a database tracking coronavirus cases

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUG.5, 2020. Grocery workers associated with UFCW Local 770 demonstrate Wednesday, Aug. 5, 2020, outside a Food 4 Less store in Los Angeles where 28 workers have allegedly become infected with COVID-19. The demonstrators called on Kroger, the parent company of Food 4 Less, to ensure safety measures in stores by providing regular COVID-19 testing, providing clear and timely information about infections and the inclusion of worker councils. (Luis Sinco/Los Aneles Time)

item.title: California to towns defying the COVID-19 shutdown: No cash for you
item.dc:creator: Hailey Branson-Potts
item.description: As coronavirus cases surge in California's rural Central Valley, a self-declared 'sanctuary city for business' is defiant, even as the state is threatening to withdraw funding. On both sides of the debate, everyone agrees: It's political.
item.content:encoded: As coronavirus cases surge in California's rural Central Valley, a self-declared 'sanctuary city for business' is defiant, even as the state is threatening to withdraw funding. On both sides of the debate, everyone agrees: It's political.

media:content.media:description: ATWATER, CA - MAY 26, 2020 - - Randy Romero, one of the few wearing a mask to prevent COVID-19, says the Pledge of Allegiance at the start of the weekly Atwater City Council meeting in Atwater on May 26, 2020. The city of Atwater in Merced County has declared itself a "sanctuary city" from the state's stay-at-home orders and has been open for business for over a week now. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California colleges can reopen with a ton of restrictions, limited dorms, online classes
item.dc:creator: Teresa Watanabe, Nina Agrawal
item.description: California colleges can reopen this fall with limited in-person classes and greatly reduced dorm life, state public health officials said Friday as they issued long-awaited guidance for how campuses can operate amid a surge in COVID-19 cases.
item.content:encoded: California colleges can reopen this fall with limited in-person classes and greatly reduced dorm life, state public health officials said Friday as they issued long-awaited guidance for how campuses can operate amid a surge in COVID-19 cases.

media:content.media:description: Bovard Auditorium seen from the steps of Doheny Library at USC. From 2006 to 2014, not a single woman ran for student body president.
media:content.media:credit: Perry C. Riddle / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Judge issues order shutting down Ventura County church's crowded, unmasked indoor services
item.dc:creator: Jake Sheridan
item.description: A Ventura County Superior Court judge Friday granted a temporary restraining order against Godspeak Calvary Chapel and pastor Rob McCoy, forbidding the church's indoor services and demanding adherence to statewide and local health orders aimed at slowing the spread of the novel coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: A Ventura County Superior Court judge Friday granted a temporary restraining order against Godspeak Calvary Chapel and pastor Rob McCoy, forbidding the church's indoor services and demanding adherence to statewide and local health orders aimed at slowing the spread of the novel coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: NEWBURY PARK, CALIFORNIA-APRIL 5, 2020-Robyn Freeman, of Orange County, came to take communion on Palm Sunday at the Godspeak Calvary Church in Newbury Park California on April 5, 2020. At the Godspeak Calvary Chapel in Newbury Park, California, communion was given inside the church on Palm Sunday using social distancing and other precautions due to coronavirus Covid 19. Pastor Rob McCoy, recently resigned from his post with the Thousand Oaks City Council because he was at odds with the city's social distancing orders. (Carolyn Cole/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Man dies attempting to save three children from drowning in Kings River
item.dc:creator: Chace Beech
item.description: A 29-year-old man has died after jumping into California's Kings River to save three children he saw struggling in the water.
item.content:encoded: A 29-year-old man has died after jumping into California's Kings River to save three children he saw struggling in the water.

media:content.media:description: Upper Kings River in California on March 18, 2017.

item.title: A judge commandeers L.A.'s City Hall in his campaign to curb homelessness
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Oreskes
item.description: Judge David O. Carter, who has ruled that local agencies must clear homeless people from encampments alongside freeways, holds a hearing at City Hall — a reflection of how a legal case has made its presence felt in L.A. politics.
item.content:encoded: Judge David O. Carter, who has ruled that local agencies must clear homeless people from encampments alongside freeways, holds a hearing at City Hall — a reflection of how a legal case has made its presence felt in L.A. politics.

media:content.media:description: Judge David Carter, a U.S. District Judge, tours a Southern California homeless encampment in Santa Ana, Calif., Wednesday, Feb. 14, 2018. Judge Carter demanded that Orange County officials provide answers about what federal funding is available to feed and temporarily house people if they are moved. (AP Photo/Amy Taxin)

item.title: Orange County's coronavirus-related death toll passes 700
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: While a far cry from the record 32 deaths reported Thursday, Friday's seven additional fatalities demonstrate that the coronavirus is continuing to take a toll even as officials weigh reopening some schools for in-person instruction.
item.content:encoded: While a far cry from the record 32 deaths reported Thursday, Friday's seven additional fatalities demonstrate that the coronavirus is continuing to take a toll even as officials weigh reopening some schools for in-person instruction.

media:content.media:description: WESTMINSTER, CA - AUGUST 05: Keith Tran, of Santa Ana, plays guitar while wearing a mask to protect himself and others from contracting COVID-19 at the Asian Garden Mall, which is closed to indoor shopping but some shops are open outdoors under tents on Wednesday, Aug. 5, 2020 in Westminster, CA. In Little Saigon in Orange County, the low number of coronavirus cases and deaths is the result of cultural habits and "consistent" behavior, according to experts and immigrants themselves. They cite three reasons: The Vietnamese are "more disciplined" in following CDC guidelines based on deep reverence for the medical profession. They already are used to wearing masks in the homeland to avoid spreading common illnesses and to protect users from dust and fumes while zipping around on mopeds, a primary method of transportation. And within extended families, people tend to appoint a representative who is the only person to venture outside buying groceries, running errands or attending to urgent matters. Dr. Quynh Kieu and her assistants - she is a pediatrician who led a major project testing about 2,000 Vietnamese American patients from May to July, resulting in just 8 positive cases. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California vows to fix coronavirus reporting system amid huge backlog of unreported tests
item.dc:creator: Taryn Luna
item.description: A series of government data failures has created a backlog of as many as 300,000 test results in California.
item.content:encoded: A series of government data failures has created a backlog of as many as 300,000 test results in California.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this April 1, 2020, file photo Dr. Mark Ghaly, secretary of the California Health and Human Services, gestures to a chart showing the impact of the mandatory stay-at-home orders, during a news conference in Rancho Cordova, Calif. A technical problem has caused a lag in California's tally of coronavirus test results, casting doubt on the accuracy of recent data showing improvements in the infection rate and number of positive cases, and hindering efforts to track the spread, the state's top health official said Tuesday., Aug. 4. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, Pool, File)

item.title: College admissions scandal: Rick Singer's employee to plead guilty to racketeering
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: In a deal with the government, Mikaela Sanford admitted that she helped fabricate profiles that depicted the children of Rick Singer's wealthy clients as decorated athletes.
item.content:encoded: In a deal with the government, Mikaela Sanford admitted that she helped fabricate profiles that depicted the children of Rick Singer's wealthy clients as decorated athletes.

media:content.media:description: BOSTON, MA - MARCH 12: William "Rick" Singer leaves Boston Federal Court after being charged with racketeering conspiracy, money laundering conspiracy, conspiracy to defraud the United States, and obstruction of justice on March 12, 2019 in Boston, Massachusetts. Singer is among several charged in alleged college admissions scam. (Photo by Scott Eisen/Getty Images) ** OUTS - ELSENT, FPG, CM - OUTS * NM, PH, VA if sourced by CT, LA or MoD **

item.title: Attorney general denounces murder charge over stillborn baby

item.content:encoded: California's top prosecutor says 'the law was misapplied' in the case of a Central Valley woman who was charged in her stillborn infant's death.

media:content.media:description: HANFORD, CALIF. - NOV. 15, 2019 - Jennifer Hernandez shows a picture of her daughter Chelsea Becker on her phone. Jennifer is the mother of a Chelsea Becker, 25, of Hanford, who was arrested Wednesday and is being held at Kings County Jail, with bail set at $5 million. charged with murder after giving birth to a stillborn baby boy with toxic amounts of methamphetamine in his system.

item.title: California congressional candidate slams Cardi B and Megan Thee Stallion's 'WAP'

item.title: With 10,000 COVID-19 deaths, California increasingly in the dark about spread
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan, Rong-Gong Lin II, Colleen Shalby
item.description: A serious breakdown in the electronic collection of coronavirus testing data has raised questions about the numbers' accuracy as the case count and death toll increases.
item.content:encoded: A serious breakdown in the electronic collection of coronavirus testing data has raised questions about the numbers' accuracy as the case count and death toll increases.

media:content.media:description: MADERA, CALIFORNIA-APRIL 8, 2020-Wanda Deselle, age 76, died of Covid 19 on April 3, 2020, in the town of Madera, California, where she worked in a medical office. Members of Jay Chapel Funeral Home bring the body to the gravesite. Immediate family had to remain in their cars as Deselle was buried on April 8, 2020. Employees of the funeral home and cemetery workers handled the burial and were the only ones allowed at the gravesite. (Carolyn Cole/Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Carolyn Cole/Carolyn Cole/Carolyn Cole/Los Angeles Times

item.title: L.A. County nears 5,000 COVID-19 deaths — half the state's total
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby, Stephanie Lai
item.description: Six months after California lost its first victim to COVID-19, the state surpassed 10,000 deaths, and Los Angeles County continues to account for the bulk of the deaths.
item.content:encoded: Six months after California lost its first victim to COVID-19, the state surpassed 10,000 deaths, and Los Angeles County continues to account for the bulk of the deaths.

media:content.media:description: Downtown Los Angeles, as seen from West Hollywood.

item.title: Prepared-food vendors at farmers markets try to battle coronavirus ban
item.dc:creator: Jake Sheridan
item.description: Restaurants and food trucks can operate but L.A. County public heath officials continue to shut out vendors who prepare food at farmers markets.
item.content:encoded: Restaurants and food trucks can operate but L.A. County public heath officials continue to shut out vendors who prepare food at farmers markets.

media:content.media:description: STUDIO CITY, CA - AUGUST 02: Siblings Carol and Phillip Kwan own Mama Musubi in Pasadena. Their business is affected by the county public health rule mandating that vendors that prepare food onsite at farmers markets can't operate during the pandemic. They haven't been able to sell food at the Studio City Farmers Market nor at four other farmers markets since about late March. Photographed at Studio City Farmers Market on Sunday, Aug. 2, 2020 in Studio City, CA. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Prosecutors reviewing case in which L.A. man alleges LAPD officers planted gun
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: Allegations that two Los Angeles police officers lied about a traffic stop and planted a gun into evidence to justify a man's arrest in 2018 are now in the hands of county prosecutors after a review by LAPD internal affairs detectives.
item.content:encoded: Allegations that two Los Angeles police officers lied about a traffic stop and planted a gun into evidence to justify a man's arrest in 2018 are now in the hands of county prosecutors after a review by LAPD internal affairs detectives.

media:content.media:description: A woman who fell out of a moving Los Angeles police car has reached a settlement with the city and officers.

item.title: L.A. might cancel real estate projects tied to City Hall corruption

item.content:encoded: A proposed ordinance would allow L.A. to revoke city approvals for real estate projects if the City Council finds developers engaged in corruption.

item.title: To slow coronavirus, a California county might pay the sick to stay home
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: Alameda County in California's Bay Area is planning to offer stipends of $1,250 for low-income residents to stay home if they have tested positive for COVID-19.
item.content:encoded: Alameda County in California's Bay Area is planning to offer stipends of $1,250 for low-income residents to stay home if they have tested positive for COVID-19.

media:content.media:description: After being sealed off to prevent overcrowding over the weekend, Oakland's Lake Merritt reopened Monday, attracting a few people out for some exercise on a sunny day.

item.title: Column: Facing a wave of evictions, California is about to make thousands of kids homeless
item.dc:creator: Erika D. Smith
item.description: In weeks, as many as 1 million families across California may be at risk of being forced out of their homes, pushed off the 'eviction cliff.'
item.content:encoded: In weeks, as many as 1 million families across California may be at risk of being forced out of their homes, pushed off the 'eviction cliff.'

media:content.media:description: EL MONTE, CA - MARCH 29: Ian Jameson (left) of El Monte organized a gathering of tenant rights activists at the El Monte City Hall to demand that the El Monte City Council pass an eviction moratorium barring all evictions during the coronavirus pandemic on Sunday, March 29, 2020 in El Monte, CA. (Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Scammers could be targeting unemployment benefits in California, state warns
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: Hit with a flood of more than 9 million applications for unemployment benefits, California is trying to identify which of them may be fraudulent.
item.content:encoded: Hit with a flood of more than 9 million applications for unemployment benefits, California is trying to identify which of them may be fraudulent.

media:content.media:description: GARDEN GROVE, CA -- THURSDAY, MAY 14, 2020: Signs are posted on the doors of the Orange County One-Stop Center in Garden Grove Thursday, May 14, 2020. Orange County One-Stop Centers are providing services by appointment. The Orange County One-Stop Center(s) provide comprehensive employment and training services. Nearly 3 million laid-off workers applied for U.S. unemployment benefits last week as the viral outbreak led more companies to slash jobs even as most states began to let some businesses reopen under certain restrictions. Roughly 36 million people have now filed for jobless aid in the two months since the coronavirus first forced millions of businesses to close their doors and shrink their workforces, the Labor Department said Thursday.(Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Eviction protections are expiring. What does this mean for struggling California tenants?
item.dc:creator: Liam Dillon
item.description: Expanded federal jobless benefits and an eviction moratorium have expired. And the biggest state protection against evictions could go away this month.
item.content:encoded: Expanded federal jobless benefits and an eviction moratorium have expired. And the biggest state protection against evictions could go away this month.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES-CA-APRIL 1, 2020: Members of the Los Angeles Tenants Union and their supporters hold a demonstration at Mariachi Plaza in Boyle Heights on Wednesday, April 1, 2020 to demand rent forgiveness for the month of April due to the coronavirus pandemic's economic fallout. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California's agency for protecting workers can't protect its own — even amid a pandemic, officials say
item.dc:creator: Jie Jenny Zou
item.description: Current and former employees at Cal/OSHA say dysfunction and vacancies have hobbled agency during ongoing crisis
item.content:encoded: Current and former employees at Cal/OSHA say dysfunction and vacancies have hobbled agency during ongoing crisis

media:content.media:description: A crew with the Los Angeles Department of Water and Power works in Encino.

item.title: Children with disabilities are regressing. How much is distance learning to blame?
item.dc:creator: Sonali Kohli
item.description: California has mandated that school districts continue to provide special education to students with disabilities during the pandemic, but has waived key timelines that allow students to receive assessments and services quickly.
item.content:encoded: California has mandated that school districts continue to provide special education to students with disabilities during the pandemic, but has waived key timelines that allow students to receive assessments and services quickly.

media:content.media:description: LYNWOOD, CA - JULY 29: From left: Myla Mann, 5, and her mother, Andrea Villalobos, pose for a portrait outside of their home on Wednesday, July 29, 2020 in Lynwood, CA. Villalobos is trying to get a special education assessment for her daughter Myla Mann, 5, but the assessments are delayed indefinitely because of COVID. Without an assessment, her daughter, Myla, can't get special education services. (Gabriella Angotti-Jones / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: How California is preparing for in-person voting this year due to coronavirus
item.dc:creator: John Myers
item.description: California elections officials are scrambling to determine how many voting locations they can muster, and how they'll find enough short-term workers to enforce coronavirus safety measures.
item.content:encoded: California elections officials are scrambling to determine how many voting locations they can muster, and how they'll find enough short-term workers to enforce coronavirus safety measures.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MARCH 3, 2020 Alicia Tamstorf holds her 5 month old Freja Tamstorf while using the new voting machine as a huge line builds with people making their way waiting almost 2 hours in a moving line before they are able to vote using the new voting machines at the UCLA Hammer Museum on Super Tuesday as people make their way to the polls March 3, 2020. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: After first being spared, rural California now being ravaged by the coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth, Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: The coronavirus is now hitting California's Central Valley the hardest.
item.content:encoded: The coronavirus is now hitting California's Central Valley the hardest.

media:content.media:description: Farmworkers weed a tomato field in French Camp, California on July 24, 2020. More than 70% of new cases of coronavirus in California's fertile San Joaquin valley are Latino workers, but advocates say they lack testing and access to care.

item.title: Ventura County firefighters rescue chickens from fiery demise
item.dc:creator: Andrew J. Campa
item.description: Ventura County firefighters rescue seven chickens from a garage fire in Camarillo on Thursday.
item.content:encoded: Ventura County firefighters rescue seven chickens from a garage fire in Camarillo on Thursday.

media:content.media:description: Members of the Ventura County Fire Department rescued and revived seven chickens that suffered smoke inhalation during a fire on Thursday afternoon at a detached garage in Camarillo Heights. The firefighters administered oxygen to the birds via children's pediatric oxygen masks.

item.title: California colleges in last-minute scramble to open without state guidance
item.dc:creator: Teresa Watanabe, Nina Agrawal, Phil Willon
item.description: Just days before fall semester is set to begin, California colleges and universities are scrambling to finalize reopening plans, but top leaders say the state's lack of guidance has frustrated efforts to bring back limited in-person learning and dorm living.
item.content:encoded: Just days before fall semester is set to begin, California colleges and universities are scrambling to finalize reopening plans, but top leaders say the state's lack of guidance has frustrated efforts to bring back limited in-person learning and dorm living.

media:content.media:description: FULLERTON-CA-APRIL 21, 2020: Cal State University Fullerton student Linh Trinh, 21, right, and her boyfriend Tan Nguyen, 21, walk around a deserted CSUF campus on Tuesday, April 21, 2020. The school is planning to begin Fall semester with online classes, one of the first universities in the nation to make that move as campuses throughout the country grapple with how long to stay closed to most students amid the coronavirus pandemic. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Ventura County sues church after indoor services without masks or distance
item.dc:creator: Jake Sheridan
item.description: Ventura County is suing pastor Rob McCoy and Godspeak Calvary Chapel, which has hosted in-person, indoor services without masks or social distance since May 31.
item.content:encoded: Ventura County is suing pastor Rob McCoy and Godspeak Calvary Chapel, which has hosted in-person, indoor services without masks or social distance since May 31.

media:content.media:description: NEWBURY PARK, CALIFORNIA-APRIL 5, 2020-At the Godspeak Calvary Chapel in Newbury Park, California, communion was given inside the church on Palm Sunday using social distancing and other precautions due to coronavirus Covid 19. Pastor Rob McCoy, right, recently resigned from his post with the Thousand Oaks City Council because he was at odds with the city's social distancing orders. (Carolyn Cole/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Grand jury charges UC Davis researcher with visa fraud and concealing membership in Chinese military
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: A federal grand jury in Sacramento charged that Juan Tang, a cancer researcher at UC Davis, committed visa fraud when she concealed her alleged membership in the Chinese military
item.content:encoded: A federal grand jury in Sacramento charged that Juan Tang, a cancer researcher at UC Davis, committed visa fraud when she concealed her alleged membership in the Chinese military

media:content.media:description: Juan Tang

item.title: 'Broken' coronavirus tracking system leaves California in the dark: 'We have no idea'
item.dc:creator: Anita Chabria, Maura Dolan
item.description: The lack of reliable test result data is disrupting pandemic response efforts, leaving officials in the dark about the spread of COVID-19.
item.content:encoded: The lack of reliable test result data is disrupting pandemic response efforts, leaving officials in the dark about the spread of COVID-19.

item.title: California tops 10,000 coronavirus-related deaths
item.dc:creator: Sean Greene, Rong-Gong Lin II, Colleen Shalby, Iris Lee
item.description: California's toll underscores how a state that was once hailed as a pandemic success story is now struggling to slow outbreaks.
item.content:encoded: California's toll underscores how a state that was once hailed as a pandemic success story is now struggling to slow outbreaks.

media:content.media:description: A Covid-19 patient is flipped by the nurses and staff at Sharp Memorial Chula Vista Intensive Care Unit. All staff wearing protective gear inside the negative pressure room on June 24th, 2020 in Chula Vista. Speaking to doctors, nurses and healthcare staff helping patients with Covid-19 at three South Bay hospitals.
media:content.media:credit: Alejandro Tamayo/The San Diego Union Tribune

item.title: Firefighters stop progress of Texas fire in Saugus at 130 acres
item.dc:creator: Andrew J. Campa
item.description: The fire in Saugus started about 2 p.m. Thursday and has grown to 130 acres, but it has not caused any structural damage and is 10% contained, officials say.
item.content:encoded: The fire in Saugus started about 2 p.m. Thursday and has grown to 130 acres, but it has not caused any structural damage and is 10% contained, officials say.

item.title: Judge hikes bail for La Luz del Mundo leader to $90 million
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: A judge set bail at $90 million for the jailed leader of La Luz del Mundo church, Naason Joaquin Garcia, who is charged with rape and possessing child porn
item.content:encoded: A judge set bail at $90 million for the jailed leader of La Luz del Mundo church, Naason Joaquin Garcia, who is charged with rape and possessing child porn

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA -AUGUST05: Naason Joaquin Garcia, the leader of the Guadalajara-based La Luz del Mundo church, at his bail hearing held at Clara Shortridge Foltz Criminal Justice Center on Wednesday, Aug. 5, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Irfan Khan/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Funeral service held for LAPD Officer Valentin Martinez, first officer to die of complications from COVID-19
item.dc:creator: Al Seib Staff photographer
item.description: Funeral service is held for L.A. Police Officer Valentin Martinez, the agency's first sworn employee to die of complications from COVID-19.
item.content:encoded: Funeral service is held for L.A. Police Officer Valentin Martinez, the agency's first sworn employee to die of complications from COVID-19.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 06: LAPD officers, family and friends attend the funeral of Los Angeles Police Department Officer Valentin Martinez, the agency's first sworn employee to die of complications from the COVID-19. The social distance memory service was held at Forest Lawn Hollywood Hills' Hall of Liberty this morning. Martinez was a 13-year veteran of the department and is presumed to have contacted the virus on duty. He was 45 when he died on July 24, 2020, leaving behind his mother, Maria Martinez, his siblings and his domestic partner, Megan Flynn, who is pregnant with their twins. Los Angeles on Thursday, Aug. 6, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: ICE deliberately limited testing at Bakersfield immigration facility with COVID-19 outbreak
item.dc:creator: Andrea Castillo
item.description: On Thursday, a federal judge in San Francisco issued a searing ruling, saying ICE has "responded to the health crisis in such a cavalier fashion" that it has "lost the right to be trusted."
item.content:encoded: On Thursday, a federal judge in San Francisco issued a searing ruling, saying ICE has "responded to the health crisis in such a cavalier fashion" that it has "lost the right to be trusted."

media:content.media:description: Hunger strikers at Mesa Verde ICE Processing Center in Bakersfield captured by drone during a sit-in protest on April 10.
media:content.media:credit: Courtesy of the California Committee for Immigrant Liberation

item.title: Then the pandemic hit. New restaurants change plans but not dreams
item.dc:creator: Faith E. Pinho
item.description: Three food-service businesses in Long Beach show adaptability and determination as they open their operations during the coronavirus pandemic.
item.content:encoded: Three food-service businesses in Long Beach show adaptability and determination as they open their operations during the coronavirus pandemic.

media:content.media:description: LONG BEACH, CA - JUNE 24: From left: Eva Ardon, 10, and her mother, Shoshanah Abraham, pose for a portrait at Getting Caked bakery on Wednesday, June 24, 2020 in Long Beach, CA. (Gabriella Angotti-Jones / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Orange County posts its highest single-day COVID death total: 32
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: The 32 newly reported fatalities pushed the county's total deaths related to the coronavirus to 697.
item.content:encoded: The 32 newly reported fatalities pushed the county's total deaths related to the coronavirus to 697.

media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, CA - JULY 28: Patrons dine under umbrellas and other portable instant shelters that have been erected for outdoor dining as restaurants have moved onto Main Street between Olive and Walnut Avenues in downtown Huntington Beach after Gov. Newsom ordered restaurants to cease indoor operations on Tuesday, July 28, 2020. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Apple fire chars over 28,000 acres, prompting new evacuations for Morongo Valley
item.dc:creator: Hayley Smith
item.description: Two days after most evacuation orders were lifted in Riverside County, the San Bernardino County sheriff warns Morongo Valley residents to leave as the Apple fire grows.
item.content:encoded: Two days after most evacuation orders were lifted in Riverside County, the San Bernardino County sheriff warns Morongo Valley residents to leave as the Apple fire grows.

media:content.media:description: CHERRY VALLEY, CA - AUGUST 1, 2020: A firefighter from Carpinteria monitors the huge plume from the out-of-control Apple fire along Bluff Street, north of Banning during the coronavirus pandemic on August 1, 2020 in Cherry Valley, California. (Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Inside the 'culture of violence' alleged by LAPD SWAT whistleblower
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector, Richard Winton
item.description: An LAPD sergeant alleging that a group of officers known as the 'SWAT mafia' corrupted the tactical unit had previously flagged the group's influence.
item.content:encoded: An LAPD sergeant alleging that a group of officers known as the 'SWAT mafia' corrupted the tactical unit had previously flagged the group's influence.

media:content.media:description: Al Seib Los Angeles Times

item.title: Drug bust at San Francisco hotel prompts new coronavirus safety measures
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: Two people were arrested for manufacturing and selling drugs at a hotel used to house homeless people who are at risk for contracting COVID-19.
item.content:encoded: Two people were arrested for manufacturing and selling drugs at a hotel used to house homeless people who are at risk for contracting COVID-19.

media:content.media:description: San Francisco, San Francisco County As you approach San Francisco, one of the first sights to welcome you will be the Golden Gate Bridge (shown here). Other "must see" places include Fisherman's Wharf and Alcatraz. Contact: San Francisco Convention & Visitors Bureau, (415) 391-2000, www.onlyinsanfrancisco.com

item.title: Hacienda Heights pastor charged with sexual assault of minors
item.dc:creator: Hayley Smith
item.description: The pastor of Abundant Life Ministries was arrested after a six-month investigation and charged with sexually assaulting young girls.
item.content:encoded: The pastor of Abundant Life Ministries was arrested after a six-month investigation and charged with sexually assaulting young girls.

media:content.media:description: Booking mug of Jonathan Tsai, 40, pastor of Abundant Life Ministries, who was arrested July 21 after a six-month-long investigation for sexually assaulting three minors.

item.title: Eighth California corrections officer dies of COVID-19
item.dc:creator: Hayley Smith
item.description: Sgt. Seeyengkee Ly spent more than 17 years with the California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation.
item.content:encoded: Sgt. Seeyengkee Ly spent more than 17 years with the California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation.

media:content.media:description: Undated handout photo of Seeyengkee Ly, a correctional sergeant at Valley State Prison in Chowchilla who has become the eighth state prison employee to die of COVID-19. Ly spent more than 17 years with the California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation and served at several facilities throughout the system.

item.title: LAPD officer shot in suspected 'friendly fire' incident in Hollywood, police say
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: A Los Angeles police officer was shot accidentally by a fellow officer while responding Wednesday to reports of a distraught man, the LAPD said.
item.content:encoded: A Los Angeles police officer was shot accidentally by a fellow officer while responding Wednesday to reports of a distraught man, the LAPD said.

item.title: Magnitude 3.2 earthquake strikes offshore near Santa Cruz
item.dc:creator: Quakebot
item.description: A magnitude 3.2 earthquake was reported at 9 a.m. Thursday off the California coast, 16 miles from Santa Cruz.
item.content:encoded: A magnitude 3.2 earthquake was reported at 9 a.m. Thursday off the California coast, 16 miles from Santa Cruz.

media:content.media:description: A magnitude-3.1 earthquake was reported at 9 a.m. Thursday, Aug. 6, 2020, 16 miles from Santa Cruz.
